Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Mitral Valve Repair vs. Replacement for Severe Ischemic Mitral Regurgitation

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 251 patients were randomised to either repair (n = 126) or replacement (n = 125)

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included severe ischemic mitral regurgitation

Intervention.evidence: randomised to either repair (n = 126) or replacement (n = 125)

Objective.evidence: to evaluate the efficacy of mitral valve repair versus replacement in patients with severe ischemic mitral regurgitation

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the recurrence of moderate/severe mitral regurgitation or death within 2 years

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the interventions, blinding was not feasible

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 251 patients were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Among the 116 patients who received repair, 76 experienced moderate/severe mitral regurgitation or died

Result_Outcome.evidence: The model, which included factors such as age, body mass index, sex, race, effective regurgitant orifice area, and history of coronary interventions, demonstrated an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 0.82

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were not detailed in the abstract
